channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: Clergy abuse survivors release report on cardinals who could be elected pope
item.description: The Vatican says sex abuse is a major topic ahead of the conclave. A survivors network has launched a project to keep the the records of those who've sheltered abusive priests in the public eye.

item.title: What to watch for when the White House releases Trump's first budget proposal
item.description: President Trump's team is expected to soon preview his first budget proposal. We explain what parts matter.

item.title: A tax loophole allowed Americans to buy lots of cheap stuff from China. Not anymore
item.description: The U.S. will start collecting import fees on small packages from China, much of which comes from Chinese e-commerce sites. Consumers are panicking.

item.title: Nominations for the 2025 Tony Awards – Broadway's highest honors – are announced
item.description: While Broadway's box office is approaching pre-pandemic levels, fewer shows are making money, so the showcase of the national Tony broadcast is an invaluable marketing tool.

item.title: Chinatowns feel the impact of Trump's tariffs
item.description: Chinatowns across the nation are vibrant, cultural and economic centers for Asian Americans, tourists and residents alike. How are they faring with the Trump administration's steep tariffs?

item.title: Waltz is out at the White House. What's next for Trump's national security adviser?
item.description: In the first big shake-up of his inner circle, President Trump said he's nominating his national security adviser Mike Waltz as his UN ambassador.

item.title: Boosting crawfish frog numbers by moving their eggs
item.description: Crawfish frog numbers are on decline due to habitat loss. But scientists in Indiana are working to return species to a historic site.

item.title: This week in science: Minecraft, perfecting a pasta dish and new cancer research
item.description: Scientists are using the video game Minecraft to study how humans learn, perfecting a classic Roman pasta dish with science, and a possible reason why more young people are getting colorectal cancer.

item.title: President Trump has taken measures to bring back timber jobs. Will they work?
item.description: Tariffs on foreign timber and an executive order suspending environmental regulations could revive a domestic logging industry. But it's unclear if the economics will support exploitation of forests.

item.title: Millennials and Gen Zers will outnumber Baby Boomers in Australia's upcoming election
item.description: A record 18 million Australians are registered to vote in Saturday's national election. And for the first time, Millennials and Gen-Z will overtake Baby Boomers to form the dominant voting bloc.
